text.author: John Hooper
text.description: Italian prime minister hits back as Veronica Lario files for divorce over husband's connections with pretty young women
text.title: Silvio Berlusconi calls on Veronica Lario to apologise amid divorce case

main.p: Silvio Berlusconi was today quoted as saying his estranged wife, Veronica Lario, should apologise to him and not the other way around.

Italy's prime minister made his comment in a front-page interview with the editor of Corriere della Sera, the country's best-selling daily, on the day after his wife announced she was beginning divorce proceedings.
The interview appears to mark the launch of a vigorous counter-offensive by the Berlusconi camp, concerned that the shattering of his second marriage could have widespread political fallout.

The already distressed Berlusconi-Lario match headed for the rocks after the prime minister was reported to have attended the 18th birthday party of a Neapolitan girl who aspires to a career in showbusiness and calls him "Daddy". Writing to a news agency afterwards, Lario concentrated her fire on her husband's selection of a string of pretty young women to be candidates for his party in next month's European parliamentary elections.
"I am indignant," Berlusconi said. "Veronica has fallen into a trap. And I know who she is being advised by. Or rather, being incited by."

Asked if there was any chance of saving his marriage, the prime minister said: "I don't think so. I don't know if I want that this time. Veronica will have to apologise to me publicly. And I don't know if it would be enough.
"It's the third time in an election campaign that she has pulled a stunt of this kind. It really is too much."
Berlusconi said the affair was the result of "media criminality". The newspaper said he believed he was the victim of a plot to ruin him at the apex of his popularity.

According to other reports today, Berlusconi's aides fear his scorned wife could launch an all-out offensive against the prime minister in interviews with magazines and TV chat shows, revealing embarrassing secrets and sensitive information.

Berlusconi said he had dropped in on the birthday party of Noemi Letizia because her father, a council employee, was a "friend of many years". Asked why she called him papi, he replied: "But it's a joke. They wanted to call me granddad. It's better they call me daddy, don't you think?"
The prime minister said three pretty young women whose candidacies were revoked after Lario's letter were not showgirls. One was an actress, he said.
